results.title: The Natural
results.creator_credit: Barry Levinson, Mark Johnson, Delphi II and Tri-Star Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Bernard Malamud, “The Natural” is one of those heroic, feel good, fairy tale films that captures the human spirit. It is a tale of boyhood dreams, of a certain defiance to turn the dream into reality and become a legend and a superhero in that passionate game of American games, baseball, and of a chance encounter with a mysterious woman that will eventually and catastrophically shatter those very dreams. Robert Redford plays the quiet and unassuming middle-aged Roy Hobbs who at the age of 14 hand-carved his own baseball bat from a tree struck down by lightning on the farm where he lived. It was Roy’s dream to play baseball in the major league and it would be his “wonder boy” bat many years later that would take him to stardom and the major league team, the New York Knights. But like all fairy tales, where good and evil battle it out, Hobbs has his own demons to deal with in the form of knockers, corruption and those who would wish to see him, and the New York Knights, fail. The story climaxes to a tense and spectacular final sequence as our hero takes the bat in a nail-biting challenge to win the pennant for his Knights. This is not a film to be taken too seriously and there are many holes in the plot, but it features a wonderful cast including Glenn Close, Kim Basinger, Robert Duvall, Barbara Hershey, Richard Farnsworth and an uncredited appearance by Darren McGavin.

results.title: Crackerjack
results.creator_credit: Paul Moloney, Stephen Luby, Mick Molloy, A Million Monkeys, Macquarie Film Corporation and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: In this laconic Australian comedy an immature thirty-something male discovers something of life when he becomes involved with an ailing local lawn bowls club under threat of closure at the hands of mercenary developers. Mick Molloy (who co-wrote the film with brother Richard) plays Jack, a shabby and exploitative ill-mannered oaf, whose interest in being a member of the club begins and ends with the cheap inner-city parking it provides. When the elderly members of the club call upon him to play the game or forfeit his membership, Jack soon learns lessons in humility, a love of the game and respect for his elderly companions. With a broad comic tone, Australian idiosyncrasies (albeit familiar ones) - excessive swearing, drinking, smoking and jokes about the sexuality of octogenarians - abound. The gender roles are well defined; women in charge of baking, whilst mateship and honour are the ideals to which men aspire. Like “The Castle” (Rob Sitch, 1997) this film embraces the classic David versus Goliath structure, as the morally sound little man faces an evil corporate developer seeking to undermine a certain spirit and camaraderie of society. Melbourne comedian Judith Lucy plays Nance, a local reporter who becomes concerned for the future of the club and forms a romantic attachment to Jack. Also stars Samuel Johnson.

results.title: The Crow: salvation
results.creator_credit: Bharat Nalluri, Jeff Most, Edward Pressman, IMF Internationale Medien und Film GmbH & Co. Produktions KG and IMF (DE)
results.brief_description: Executed on his 21st birthday, Alex Corvis (Eric Mabius) proclaimed his innocence until the end and attributed the horrific murder of his girlfriend to a mystery man with a distinctively scarred arm. Now dead, the former prisoner is brought back to life by a crow who leads Alex to salvation, revenge and justice. Along the way he also gets to save the virtue of several young women imperilled by a corrupt posse of police and investigates a conspiracy theory involving his murdered girlfriend. Thanks to some carefully applied face paint, Alex is unrecogniseable to all who knew him, although don’t expect any great scenes of transformation as Alex is content to stay in his prison garb. Moving from one brutal encounter to another, Alex eventually discovers the real killer leaving a body count and bloody trail behind him. Relentlessly and gratuitously violent, this is the third instalment in the million dollar Crow franchise that hit the big screen in 1994, directed by Alex Proyas and starring Brandon Lee in his ill fated last screen performance. Cast also includes William Atherton, Grant Shaud and Jodi Lyn O’Keefe.

results.title: McLintock
results.creator_credit: Andrew V McLaglen, Michael Wayne and Batjac Productions
results.brief_description: Oklahoma cattle baron George Washington (GW) McLintock, feared and respected, is also the eponymous McLintock of McLintock hamlet. He is reputedly afraid of nothing, except his estranged wife Katie (Maureen O’Hara) who has unexpectedly returned from the East Coast to try and convince their daughter Becky (Stefanie Powers) to join her in the city. During the period of separation (and rather close to her return), GW has employed new ranch hand Devlin (Patrick Wayne) who is beginning to enjoy the company of his daughter, as well as Devlin’s mother, Louise (Yvonne De Carlo), who will soon be a cause of jealousy for the returned Mrs McLintock. Littered with stereotypes that don’t stand the test of time, Wayne and O’Hara have plenty of fun bantering as they did in “The Quiet man” and “Rio Grande”. With plenty of sight gags, the film culminates in an infamous spanking scene in which Wayne places the wet undergarment clad O’Hara on his knee, giving her what he considers to be her dues.

results.title: Tapeheads
results.creator_credit: Bill Fishman, Peter McCarthy, Pacific Arts, National Broadcasting Company, Front Films and De Laurentiis Entertainment Group
results.brief_description: A satire on the music business, “Tapeheads” is about two childhood friends who, after losing their jobs as security guards decide to scam their way into the music video industry. Ivan (John Cusack) is the exuberant friend who is accustomed to getting the more reserved Josh (Tim Robbins) into trouble. Forming Video Aces, Ivan encourages Josh to develop his creativity whilst the business-like Ivan helms the operation. Initially the pair work on a hilarious rapping commercial for a chicken and waffle outlet and a dying man’s video-will. Whilst doing the thankless rounds of the production companies, Ivan meets music impresario Mo Fuzz, and after hiring them (on spec) they embark upon their first successful rock music video. From there the irrepressible duo encounter all manner of swindles and mishaps on a twisted route to success. This film tapped into the cultural moment that was the origins of the MTV generation with a fast paced script and rapid editing, but perhaps the filmmakers were ahead of their time because despite its infectious and irreverent humour “Tapeheads” was a box-office failure. Cameos includes Weird Al Yankovich, Ted Nugent, Jello Biafra, Junior Walker and Sam Moore.

results.title: Penny serenade [DVD]
results.brief_description: Leaving her husband, a woman contemplating divorce recollects in a series of flashbacks the story of her courtship and marriage, the shattering loss of her unborn child, financial struggles, and the emotional upheaval of adopting a child. Stars Irene Dunn and Cary Grant.

results.title: A Star is born [DVD]
results.creator_credit: William Wellman, David O. Selznick and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: The rise of a small-time singer to Hollywood stardom is matched by the decline of her actor-mentor, then husband. A melodrama, a musical comedy and a musical-within-a-musical which, beneath its mythmaking about Hollywood, achieves a rare depth of emotion and sense of truthfulness. Cast includes Janet Gaynor, Frederic March, Adolphe Menjou and May Robson.

results.title: Charade [DVD]
results.brief_description: A Parisienne (Audrey Hepburn) finds her husband murdered. Four strange men are after her, and she is helped by a handsome stranger (Cary Grant)… but is he a hero, spy or a murderer? A mammoth audience teaser bursting with multiple identities, smart Parisian settings and Henry Mancini music. The song Charade was nominated for an Academy Award, lyrics by Johnny Mercier.

results.title: The Story of Seabiscuit = Pride of Kentucky
results.creator_credit: David Butler, William Jacobs and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Irishman Shawn O’Hara (Barry Fitzgerald), a horse trainer with the gift of being able to tell whether a yearling is going to be a winner or not, arrives in Paris, Kentucky, with his niece, Margaret (Shirley Temple) to take up a position at Millford Farms. He is drawn to a horse called Seabiscuit which initially no-one else credits with winning. At the same time a romance slowly blossoms between his niece and jockey Ted Knowles (Lon McCallister). Margaret is reticent at falling in love with a jockey however as she has already lost her brother, also a jockey, when he fell to his death while riding one of Shawn’s horses. The incident caused uncle and niece to flee their native Ireland. Written by John Taintor Foote. Music by David Buttolph. Filmed in Technicolor.

results.title: The Fabulous Baker boys
results.creator_credit: Steve Kloves, Paula Weinstein, Mark Rosenberg, Gladden Entertainment and Mirage Enterprises
results.brief_description: The Baker brothers, Frank and Jack, have been playing together for thirty-one years, as piano accompanists, in an array of bars and nightclubs. In the throes of a dead-end career, the cynical Jack is particularly embittered by their lack of success and thwarted dreams of glory that has resulted in a slew of bad gigs at sleazy dives. Frank, a responsible father of two who worries for their finances, is willing to take any gig for a buck. But Jack is resentful of Frank’s passivity and inability to defend his honour or art. Increasingly unemployable, the brothers hire a singer to spruce up their act - and Susie Diamond, ballsy, rough, lower class but talented, transforms them into a classy act. The alluring presence of the sexy Susie creates tensions for the brothers who are forced to address the inequities and rivalry that mars their relationship. Although the formula of the outsider who upsets the dynamics of a long-standing show-biz relationship has been used frequently in cinema, “The Fabulous Baker boys” still engages and entertains, greatly assisted by the stellar performances of the leads, Jeff and Beau Bridges and Michelle Pfeiffer and an array of sultry tunes.
